commentBody: I'm guessing you pulled a Ken Jennings on 19D :) https://youtu.be/KoPFkjF-Bdo

not complaining, but where i come from, the phrase was upsy daisy.  not upsa daisy.  

variations are good.
Great puzzle with a clever theme! I too was thrown by UPSA Daisy instead of UPSY. But this was a fun solve and could’ve worked as a Wednesday or a Thursday lite. Nice job, constructors!

I found nothing to CARP about in this puzzle (except my personal preference for upsy over UPSA in reference to daisy).  I enjoyed the clever themers, especially THETAMINGOFTHECREW and NOGREATCAKES.  As a relative geographical illiterate I was unfamiliar with ALAI and didn’t know the URAL was a river.

Speaking of rivers, I’d better get back to building an ark, because it’s raining buckets here in PA.  Luckily Ardmore means something akin to great height in Gaelic.

About that poker tournament I played in on Sunday, I didn’t win. I blame being too tired. Kept falling asleep during breaks. But I . . . GAVE IT MY BEST COT. A very nice Tuesday-Weds. combination! Don’t forget to vote for the Puzzles of the Year: https://nyti.ms/3vrwcVA#permid=130301756 Vote by Recommending.
A very meaty Wednesday.  Some great misdirection clues - eg 30A (Often in stock = BONE).  Not too difficult but well worthy of a NYT crossword.

In honor of yesterday:

Coffee break used to complain about the use of “octopi”?


TEN O’CLOCK CARP

My time doesn’t reflect this. But this was the hardest puzzle for me in 2024.  By far. 

I was ‘annoyed’ I struggled so much for a ‘Wednesday’. But I loved it. 

Nothing came easy. And what came easy was wrong every time.  When I finally cracked the revealer, it all clicked. 


I can’t even remember or list everything I did wrong. But isn’t CASE a good answer for “making or breaking?’  Thought the mountain range was URAL. But no, it’s a river. 

But I guess I’ll nitpick and say GESTS doesn’t seem like tales of daring.  But maybe I don’t know what daring means. I BONE in stock?  Or bones?

TYPEO was just a great “those letters don’t make sense together” answer.

Anyway. The theme was clever.  I enjoyed the phrases and the clues and the fill.  

Thanks constructors!
I’ve never heard “upsa” either.  But I favor “oopsy” above both.
I’m looking for the Wordplay column on Adam Wagner’s Tuesday puzzle.  I also tried the Wordplay search function.

A few observations from me about this fun puzzle and fun team-up of Chloe and Alissa:

(1) Like others, I had UPSy before UPSA, which played games with the revealer for me. For a bit, it looked like part of 60A would be SCyRING ... or is that scrying?

(2) Even after that was straightened, I still need to mouth the revealer a few times to catch on to the replacement.

(3) I needed that understanding to go back and solve 17A. Part of the problem was that I had CAse before CAMP (you can make a case or break a case, right?), and so I thought this themer might be requiring the coxswain to tase the rowers. Ah, no.

Other than those hiccups, this was a smooth solve. I love the fresher cluing of ECO (we've had our fill of greens lately) and ORCA (hey, that's a killer clue about brain size). 

Sam, regarding your column title, subtitle, column photo and caption, it seems to me that Chloe and Alissa are "best buds" when it comes to SHARING the duties for creating this crossword, as exemplified by the two flowers in the photo. The finished grid reflects a lot of CARING on their part about our solving experience. And their love of crosswords, like ours, may "stem" from childhood.

Fun, went smoothly, but I have never seen the term gest.  The dictionary supports the definition though.  Enjoyed the clever theme and revealer.  Kept struggling with abstain, couldn't see how the answer fit.  Doh.

Did the puzzle Tuesday night with our daughter, who came to higher ground to escape the monsoons in New Jersey.  Fun puzzle and clever execution of the theme.  GIFTCOP and ALAI were the new words for us, but readily solved with the crosses.  Well done, constructors!

Our family’s gold star streak hit the happy number 1234 today!

A quiet, wet night
What's with all these Gs and Cs?
Good Crossword, maybe

A puzzle with a clever theme and some late week level cluing, I thought.   I figured out the revealer fairly early, which helped me get the first theme answer, which in turn helped me in the NW corner, where I had nothing.

Our coxswain is so oar-nery. We always get into a row with him.

(He's such a num-scull.)
Loved this. Pretty darn crunchy for a Wednesday!
Just a really enjoyable puzzle - well clued and a witty theme.

A fun puzzle for a Wednesday.  Plenty of punny mis-directs like the clues for IMAC, TYPEO, BONE, MITT, RUG, EARS, ELS, TOGAS, AGES and RTE.

Puzzlemucker’s description of a recent experience in a card tournament reminded me of an unforgettable incident in a Las Vegas casino my wife and I visited when Sam was literally a babe in arms.  We were walking on a red carpet taking us through the casino on our way to our hotel.  (Clever folks who design hotels containing casinos.  Not unlike the designers of drug stores whose main entrance invariably makes you first walk through the cosmetics departments.) We paused briefly in front of a bank of slot machines, taking a step off the carpet.  We were immediately accosted by a security guard who told us that no-one under 21 was permitted in the casino!
Great puzzle! Could some kind soul explain 42D to me? I filled it in with crosses, but don’t get what it’s referring to.

Toughest Wednesday puzzle for me in a long time.

At home, I typically solve  the puzzle before going to sleep between 10 and 11. 

We’re on a ski trip to Utah, so the puzzle is available at 8:00 instead of 9:00. That’s of little help when you’re so tired that staying awake much past dinner is a struggle. 

I started this after getting in bed and got a third of it done before getting too sleepy to finish, something that never happens at home. When I put down my iPad, I had done about a third of the puzzle and had no idea what the theme was. 

But I woke up after a few hours and couldn’t get back to sleep, so I decided to finish the puzzle. It was still a challenge — my first attempt to fill in 17A was based on some half-thought-out pun on “oar” until the “SH is C” theme became apparent. 

Thanks for the fun challenge, Ms Revery and Ms Revness! I’m looking forward to the next collaboration from y’all.
Could someone please explain "they're raised in Chi-town" to me? Non-American here and I think it's gone waaay over my head.

I will say, upon seeing "a dance floor flourish" as a clue for a three letter clue, the first cross of which was that the first letter was D...I felt a twinge of fear. 
"It couldn't possibly be DAB." I thought.
"Please dear god let it not be DAB." 

Thankfully it was DIP. The relief was powerful.

Funnest Wednesday in recent memory!

With _NIC_, I stared at 52D for an embarrassingly long time.

I'm TYPE O (negative) but that was a headslap when I finally saw it.

I learned interesting things, like GOBI

It felt a little difficult for a Wednesday, which is also nice.
This was really tricky and I needed lots of help, but it was all worth it when I suddenly noticed the SH sound for C.   Very impressive construction and a fun solve.

Somehow I managed to complete this (basically I had to sit there adding a letter to '_IP' until I realised it was 'DIP' which made OPT_D explain where buds go that definitely wasn't CANS, CARS or BARS. 

Anyway, enjoyed understanding the theme bit which allowed me to actually get the answers to those acrosses.

I had not realized that the solution to 38A, GIFT COP, was part of the theme until I read the Wordplay column.  I assumed it was a real term because when my large extended family gets together for Christmas, my older sister directs who opens which presents in which order, so we call her the "gift cop."  So when I read the clue, I knew the answer immediately because I thought it was a widely accepted term!

Cute theme with some very clever clues.  My TIL was the central Asian mountain range:  ALAI?  HAI!  

Well done and thanks.

A MITT catches, not catching. Now I join the ranks of those who quibble over nothing.  ko is mocking me.

Thank you Chloe and Alissa a fun solve.
Fun theme entries and a bunch of clever clues made this an enjoyable Wednesday.  Thanks, Chloe and Alissa, you work well together.

A bit of a struggle this morning: I'm fasting before an annual physical, and comprehensive screening of my TYPE O blood, so no coffee for me this morning. But it appears many others struggled as well. re 41A: on doing my "on-line check-in", I was surprised to discover that I was an asexual atheist: no HOTS or CULTS for me. Here's the British rapper Chipmunk, who knows how to spell 48D correctly: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fkXTG-AmzEA

Very smart theme! Loved it!

Thank you, Chloe and Alissa!
See ya soon!

emu food
more emu food

Sweet bite, slow-to-unravel reveal, cluing wit, and the feeling that I’m in the hands of a most capable constructing team – this was a wow for me.

As a veteran solver, I come into Wednesday expecting a fairly breezy outing, but this one had its share of headwinds – a treat!  A good number of answers that I couldn’t get right off from the clue, but when they eventually filled in, they made perfect sense.

Then the relatively slow awakening of the theme.  I got the C-for-SH substitution fairly early, but I left the reveal blank and tried to figure it out, first without reading its clue (no hope), then by revealing one letter at a time, and even then it took uncovering a plenitude of letters to get.  And when I finally did get it, it brought a huge “Hah!” and “Yes!” and “Perfecto!”

By the way, the puzzlemakers are kin-structors, aunt and niece, which makes my family-loving heart smile.  And man, they created a cracker-jack gem today.  Alissa and Chloe, I hope to see SAMOA from you, and soon.  Thank you so much for this!

Shirley you gest.

Where was I? Oh yeah - nice puzzle and really clever theme. Much to my surprise I actually caught on to the trick fairly early and was having a surprisingly smooth Wednesday solve. And then...  just got stuck in the NW corner for quite a while. On reflection I can't understand why; it all looks obvious now. Oh well, no big deal. I liked it. 

15 letter answer that dawned on me today led to a rather remarkable puzzle. I'll put that in a reply. 

..

Yes, it's "upsy".
And "yowls"? No.
“Upsa”-daisy? Really? I’ve never seen anyone spell it like that.
Hey, by the way… I never heard the phrase “OH SAY”

Upsa? 
Oh say? 
🥴



No emu or emuesque emoji, but here’s a dodo and a flamingo 🦤🦩

I'm going to come down in favor of UPSA daisy - as in what you might say when you lift a small child. AT first I thought it might be a variant of oopsie daisy (or however you spell that) - what you might say when you make a small error. But, UPSA daisy makes sense to me when I say it out loud.

Today's "octopi" is "upsa".

In the words of Jack Nicholson in "Easy Rider" as he took a slug from the liquor bottle, "nit, nit, nit".

Not really a fan of the crossword nit game.  If I can get to the answer from the clue and the crosses, I don't care if I've heard of the answer or not. In just about every case, if you haven't heard of it, someone else has.

I enjoyed the puzzle very much. No quibbles about usages that weren't as familiar to me. I sure needed the revealer to figure out what was going on!  Thanks for the fun, constructors! And editors! Where's Letterbox?

I was on the same wavelength as the constructors for the most part, but then thought MICS and IMAC might be wrong & wasted a lot of time. Had PACT instead of CAMP. Didn’t get TYPEO except thru fills, even though I had the Y and the O (D’oh!) Good Wednesday

Oh boy. Solved it unaided, but took over twenty minutes.

NOTDO? UPSA? GESTS? ALAI (clued as "Kyrgyzstan mountain range")? I suppose that resonates with GOBI in some indirect way, though it seems obscure compared to the much longer ALTAI range. Unless you're in Kyrgyzstan, perhaps.

I suppose SHARINGISCARING specifies that SH is C, i.e., that SH <--> C, but this theme and revealer just didn't excite me. Same for much of the fill.

Think I'd have sent this one back.

Lovely puzzle, lovely haikus, lovely column, sad little oil duck. Thanks, team.

Also, on behalf of my daughter's SO, a coxswain with a budding familiarity of Shakespeare, thank you for 17A. I'm glad not all your darlings were lost.
OT at Duke starting 6 months of weekly injections and pills treatment for multiple myeloma. Hoping no side effects that would break my steak! Will try to check in now and again. Play nice!

Alyssa Haikus.
See, I used that as a verb?
Is "upsa" a word?


thanks emus
(I think upsa is fine, even though absolutely no one says it that way.)

That was a very hard puzzle for me, and not only because I am hopeless with understanding most NYT puzzle themes. Some of the trivia was really, REALLY niche. I am generally good with geography, and I know the names of many quite exotic mountain ranges but ALAI was completely new to me. It seemed like overkill on a Wednesday.

Also, I still do not understand some clues.

Marine leader? ULTRA - what is that about?
GESTS almost beat me as did UPSA (upsy?).  Seems like I wasn't alone in the struggle. Fortunately the crosses were clear and I learned something new.  Loved the theme.

I enjoyed the last two puzzles, and I liked their themes, but I found the revealers somewhat lacking. Tuesday does not mean (or sound like) "two days". "Sharing is caring" is not the same as "change sh to c". Perhaps I would like it better if the revealer clues were different, but as it is, I don't find either one too convincing.

The final solve for me came from correcting “NOCREAMCAKES” to “NOGREATCAKES” (after some assistance from the tricky clues!).

Although I’d suggest no cream cakes would be another acceptable reason for a poor review!

Tough for a Wednesday, but fun.  The NW corner was a huge challenge because I kept trying to put DATE and some plural form of VIRUS in there (yes, I know there's no weird form of VIRUS, but I was getting desperate.)

TIL that Thor is the protector of humankind. I knew he was Norse already but what a nice guy. 

I thought the theme was clever and fun, got stuck on the NW with 1A, which was my last fill and I had to get it from the crosses.
Should be “oopsy” if anything

Hmm I learned the phrase NOGREATSHAKES today. Hadn’t heard that before. 

I had KIDSCONE for way too long.

Fun puzzle. I’m in the UPSy camp — never heard or seen UPSA-daisy. But since the word is essentially just a nonsensical transcription of a spoken interjection, it seems churlish to CARP about the precise spelling — and while it made me doubt my UPSA/SHARING IS CARING for a minute, once I said “upsa-daisy” out loud to myself I realized it was fine. 

Liked the themers a lot. As a hasbeen rower who spent much of my college years in an eight, I appreciated 17A. And 49A earned a chuckle and still makes me smile. 

Thanks Chloe and Alissa for a fun Wednesday.

For some reason (mercy, accident, bowing to popular demand) the puzzle and clues were 'normal' in size today....  Thank you!

OOPSY-daisy, and just *maybe* (if you're Hugh Grant) UPSY-daisies, but UPSA?  Just NO, even if it IS only Wednesday.   And then there is the Kyrgyzstan mountain range, but at least that isn't a faked-up word.  

Isn't there a saying about not looking a GIFT COP in the mouth?  We followed a tradition in our family:  presents are opened on Christmas morning, one at a time, so that everyone can enjoy the surprise and pleasures of giving and receiving.  Policing was never required, and not even the youngest one ever complained  

My fave is the Kurt Vonnegut quote.  PhysicsDaughter is at the AIAA conference in Orlando (said her presentation went well) and she's the first person I'll share that quote with.  Wink!  (She is in a minority--masking--and says there is a lot of coughing going on.  Hope THOR is on the job.)

Must go read the column to see if we have a debut puzzle here, which might account for the leniency....    
but thinking of all you solvers in the path of this storm system.  It appears our state got off lightly in comparison.

When googling Kyrgyzstan mountain ranges Alai is the 8th one that shows up. Very obscure, not the countries most famous range. Maybe it's better to redo the grid rather than reach that far to force the grid to work. 

Shout out to all the 78 year olds who knew the song reference. I'm assuming you would need to be at least 10 years old in 1956 for a song to be in your common knowledge.

Frustrating puzzle for me.
Regarding GRAINIER, the clue is misleading. Just because footage is grainy, doesn’t mean it is out of focus.

I learnt that "Kyrgyzstan mountain range" = ALAI. Much preferred to the old standby "Jai ____" 
Happy Wednesday. Hope everyone is safe from recent storms.
One should never put buds in one’s ears. Just saying!

Am I the only one who can’t see how NOTDO fits for the clue “Abstain from”?

“I abstain from drinking”
“I NOT DO drinking”

???

Generally frustrated with this puzzle. Just not vibing with the cluing, I guess.

Loved it.  The theme was a lot of fun and the theme answers were well-chosen and well-clued.  But the constructors obviously put a lot of thought into all the clues, with some really nice ones for AGES; TWO (interesting factoid); GOBI; ORCA (another interesting factoid); and especially TYPEO, which baffled me for the longest time.

I got NO GREAT CAKES before I got the TAMING of TAMING OF THE CREW.  But once I had the former, the latter became obvious.  But what would the revealer be?  I tried to think of one and couldn't.  SH=C?  Sort of like E=MC-squared?  Nothing came to me.

But SHARING IS CARING is nicely unguessable, unexpected, and works quite well, I think.  An entertaining puzzle to work on.
My takeaway from today's puzzle is that GOBI Desert is redundant. Mongolians are laughing at us. (Also, Sahara is Arabic for desert.)

* "Crowmalion" playwright?
-
-
-
-
-
-
-
-
-
GEORGE BERNARD CAW

I loved this.   Don’t know why there is always so much 44-acrossing all the time.  I think we’re all smart enough to know how sometimes you have to bend a little to make it all work. Ooopsy, upsy, upsa…. Did it really stop anyone from completing the puzzle?    Some people might even say upsa (pssst,  it’s not even a real word)

That said…. When will an apple just be a fruit again?  😋
What fun! This was challenging enough to keep me guessing and clever enough to deliver the payoff. Thank you, Chloe and Alissa, for a terrific puzzle. I'm looking forward to more like it.

Incredibly difficult one for me! I'm not sure why I struggled so much. I had CAse for "Something to make or break," which was giving me _YEEO. (And I'm O- and a regular blood donor!) Just couldn't make the leap to TAMING... either. (And I love Shakespeare! Read that play multiple times!) Somehow I've never, ever heard the word GEST either (and I'm a former lit major!) and had a rebus in the G square.

Fie!!! A pox on this cursed puzzle! 

Okay now back to work.
Tricky but fun puzzle! Sam, my mom and I love your description about TYPEO I tried to make the same justification for a second
Glad other people enjoyed it, but I was not a fan of today's fill
your partner is a smart guy
Definitely not a Wednesday puzzle. Thursday  for me.

Super fun puzzle this morning and I loved the theme - completed more than 90% of it without any lookups which is a record for me. As with most puzzles you have to think outside the box with some of the less obvious clues (NOTDO and CULTS for me today)
Loved the puzzle. For a while, though, I thought Gift cop was a pun on Shift cop and couldn't understand why there was a "G" instead of a "C" in the "SH"substitution. Duh....
Very clever and a tough Wednesday for me. I needed help a few times. Thank you Chloe and Alissa.
It's "upsy daisey", not "upsa daisey".

Never heard of taking down a campsite referred to as “breaking camp.”  Clear answer to “something to make or break” is CASE, and held me up for nearly 30 min as a result.  I wonder when something like occurs, is the constructor deliberately being tricky with the solver knowing they will initially assume CASE, and then have to backtrack, or is it just a coincidence or lazy/thoughtless clueing?  Hoping the former, but it always feels like the latter especially when muttering profanities after 20 plus minutes of head scratching.  It’s a weird thing with these puzzles, there can be such a fine line between fun/clever/tricky and downright annoying.  And of course others may have not considered CASE for this clue as their first guess (though I’d find that nearly impossible to believe).

Tales of daring = GESTS?
I know from Beau Geste, but that's a HUGE reach. 
And not JESTS?
Saw "Boys in the Boat" last weekend so 17A made me laugh.  Fun puzzle all around, thanks, Chloe and Alissa.
Definitely had some trouble with this initially. So I left and came back and got a couple here and there and took some risks which paid off.

"Upsa"?

Was mildly flummoxed by some of the answers to some of the clues but that particular one encapsulates the odd prism that this puzzles gleams through.

Thank goodness one can turn to the sudoku puzzles as a chaser.
I know I have seen it in the crossword-verse before, but the phrase UPSA Daisy can never replace OOPSIE Daisy in my brain.

I think the difference between me and half the commenters on these crossword puzzles is that when I don't know a phrase, I think, "Huh. I didn't know that phrase" and when half the commenters don't know a phrase, they think, "this is not a real phrase and I'm mad the crossword constructor made it up just to spite me specifically."
Employing my usual metjhodology I completed the puzzle without reference to the starred clues then worked back from there to get the gimmick. And it was worth the trouble. "sh" is "c". Very nice!

Finishing this puzzle was quite a GEST for me. Or was it a fEaT, which is what I had at 49D for a damaging amount of time. I felt quite confident about it too.  In fact, I'd probably still be staring at it if I didn't say to myself: Self, you know it's fEaTS so just go look it up to confirm it! (I swear I only wanted it confirmed!) Ope!  

I had ETHAN since my first round and I had IN THAT CASE, so I was trying to figure out something like a HARe...as in a hare and the tortoise, ETC. Ha! I was really stretching! Ah well!  Que SERA SERA!

Fun theme, though I didn't really get it get it until I finished and read the column. I really enjoyed the clues for SNEER, EARS, and AGES!  I also loved seeing references to Umberto ECO and Dorothy Parker for WIT.  And I also learned a bunch of things I did not know: Self, try to remember them!
Not quite fun and more than a tad obnoxious. Hope tomorrow’s is better

When you type the word "typo"
Make sure to type "o"
Because if you type "e"
Then that's called a typo
Because you've typed a different word.

And don't try to correct that typo
By merely typing "o" after "type"
Because that's just another typo
Even though we can all accept that term.

And whatever you do
Don't compound that typo
By typing another "e"
Because then you might be viewed as type B
Whose mind dreams of the South Pacific.
I need help understanding 42-down what ELS are raised? I'm very confused.
Don't love non-standard spelling. It used to be indicated in the clue.

Wonderful puzzle. Just the right amount of trickiness. So clever! After I had a good amount of fill, I tried to work out the theme answers. Yes! So fun to then finish the puzzle. CAMP and TYPEO were the last to fall

Loved it. Had to come back to it and finish late in the day, and finally it all came together. I had the revealer early on (SHARING IS CARING), but it still took me some time to get the full picture of what was going on. Thanks so much for the fun, Chloe and Alissa. 😊
Not to be mean but this was not a strongly constructed puzzle
Lots of clever clues.
Got the whole puzzle without the key, but even when I read the explanation, it makes little sense.   No wordplay, just a “guess what I’m thinking”.    I agree this was not well-constructed.
What was the HO_S I was supposed to infer from the Tricky Clues section?

Guess I wasn’t the only one who struggled a bit with this.  I was afraid I might have to “take the blue”, and for a Wednesday no less!  Cut and thrusted with it most of the day.  It wasn’t till I finally clocked out, sat on the couch, and beamed all of my mental energies onto it, that I was able to finish.  T_PEO evaded me for the longest.
Regarding the Doris Day song, my parents were not even teenagers when it came out and yet I am very familiar with it.  Perhaps you’ve never seen the excellent 80’s dark comedy “Heathers” or had the pleasure of standing in a packed football stadium singing in full voice,
Que sera, sera
Whatever will be, will be
We’re going to Wem-bley
Que sera, sera

Here's to teachers!
This was a tricky one and I liked that for me the theme fell together at about the same pace as the puzzle as a whole. The clues were fair and fairly misleading, except, a RUG on the ground? Hmmmm. When I'm camping a rug goes on the ground outside the tent but that's about the only time, so is floor interchangeable with ground, or am I missing something?
Here for the obligatory Sneed's Seed and Feed reference.

Fun but harder than usual for Wednesday, and must confess I filled it all out and didn’t see the trick til I read the column and then had that oh, duh, feeling. TypeO got me for a while, but it was my favorite clue.
Wednesday puzzle is the new Thursday puzzle.  Hooray!

I get the super experienced people having no issues with today, but as a somewhat newbie, it just seemed a lot harder than most Wednesdays. I did another Wed back in July and finished it an hour faster than this one with no helps. I get the theme with C and SH swap etc but cmon, this was a bit closer to and end of week puzzle IMHO
love the vonnegut clue, should do more classic authors.
Finally finished in the northeast corner. I tried WAILS and BAWLS before finally coming around to YOWLS. Lots of five-letter caterwauling options.  Tough Wednesday!

Wow - a tough one for me today! Had to rely on Deb’s explanations, plus a few comments to get through. Just not on the constructors’ wavelength today, but do appreciate the time and care they put into this. Thank you!
Loved the TYPE-O clueing!!!
Too many clues that were overly obtuse or too clever by half.

pollyq,

I waited for the cross to enter the last letter.  
I grew up with "upsy" but I've heard both.

Is your spider "itsy bitsy" or something else? 





emus, though...

N.B.

My childhood spider 
was pronounced
"eensy weensy."

I've seen it written "incy wincy,"
but I'm not sure how that 
spelling is pronounced
(I assume short i's?).
@Barry Ancona itsy bitsy spiders.  And: upsy daisy.

Marshall,

Stay dry there on the Main Line
I see there is no R5 or Keystone service.






raining emus?

@Marshall Walthew 
I was thinking Ural as well until the crosses ruled it out. It is a mountain range in Russia and Kazakhstan, but it doesn’t extend far enough south to have any part in Kyrgyzstan. The ALAI range is much farther south and was new to me today. It has been clued as a mountain range a good number of times before, but the term is much more commonly clued related to the court sport also called Basque pelota (jai ALAI).

Puzzlemucker, 

While you were out...

Kentucky Eva 
thought the Monday puzzle
was a good one!







Eva, not emu

@Barry Ancona 

Terrific!  Not sure if she ever reads any other comments, including replies to her comments, but I will try to catch her next time she’s here to see if she has any favorite org. she’d like to receive a donation.

@Puzzlemucker 
Poker tourney?  Whut!

Deets!
Texas holdem?   Did you cash?

Any all ins saved by the river?






#twosevenoffsuit

@Newbie 

I felt the same way. Nothing came easy. 

For instance, I had NO LIKE THAT for a long time, Yells instead of Yowls, and the NW was impossible.

Loved it all.

@Newbie 

There are both a river and a mountain range in Russia and Kazakhstan named Ural. I don’t think I had ever heard of the river until I started solving lots of crosswords.
@PB — Or “upsy”. That was my guess on my initial run through the grid.
@PB I agree with you on oopsy, but it has too many letters and Ngram indicates upsy is more commonly used than either of the other two spellings. See: http://tinyurl.com/4ffra362 — — — — — — — —
@PB oopsy daisy means "oops" to me.
@Trish Posting from phone. Hope this link works https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/08/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2024-01-09.html #emu

@Henry Su 

Henry you've really parsed the puzzle nicely, but I'm here to really applaud your last remarks to Sam regarding the photo choice: just perfect marks. I also thought that the misdirect of what buds are put into (I had cans and taps and jars there for a while) might have also stumped Sam for a bit, because the buds in her photo look to be in a very jar-like container...but your deeper read I think is right on.

@john ezra 

Thank you very much.

My guess is that the container in the photo is a glass vase; we're just looking at it from the top.

In the puzzle, however, if the buds aren't going into one's EARS, then they probably should go IN THAT CASE.
@Tom Gift Cop was part of the theme, not a widely used term I believe!

@Jurga 

Chicago (a/k/a “Chi-Town”) is known for its system of (mostly) elevated commuter trains, which are commonly referred to as L’s. But since most crossword puzzles don’t have two-letter answers, in crossworld, the trains are ELS.

@Francis DeBernardo 

When I was growing up. We didn’t have too much money. So we all took turns watching each other open gifts. Carefully unwrap the paper. Fold it up for reuse. Carefully take gift out of box/packaging, for return purposes.  Take pictures.  It took a long time even without a lot of presents. 

My wife’s family. My first Christmas with these animals.  They all ripped open their gifts in parallel. The hedonistic ritual was over in like 5 minutes.  I was in shock and awe and sadness. But somehow as time has gone by. They’ve adopted my style of Christmas gift opening, kinda.  
I think this past Christmas took over 30 minutes.

@B The train in Chicago is called the L (and today I learned that’s actually short for elevated).

@Roy 

Are you referring to UPSA, or something else?  

If it was UPSA, if you read the comments, there are people who say UPSA, who say UPSY, OOPSIE, and a whole variety of other spellings.  It's basically a nonsense sound that has many versions.  UPSA sounds most normal to me, but others grew up with one of the other versions.

The "Var." signal appears very sparingly in the NYT puzzles, particularly when the variant spelling is exceedingly rare or strange-looking. There have only been six in all of the 20s so far.  Some weird spellings signaled that way have been EGIS, ANTEED (gambling), ENGRAINS, GAYETY, TIRO, IGUL, SHWA (the upside-down e sound), and TIPI (the shelter).

If you really don't want to be mean, you should enunciate what specifically you didn't like about it.

To me, the theme made perfect sense, and I didn't have any issue with any other clue or answer.

In 2020, my youngest graduated and was home applying to medical schools during the pandemic.

Unlike his parents, he did so many cool things. 
One of them was to learn to speak Japanese.

He would pay for FaceTime calls with people in Japan to just chat with him for an hour in the evenings.

I remember that sounding like “somethingsomethingsomething…
hai, hai…somethingsomething…hai, hai, hai…”

I was far more impressed by his conversations than my ability to pop in the answer today, but loved the memory.

(And I may or may not have secretly taped him on my phone because it was such fun to listen to, and I may or may not listen to those recordings now)
Upsy????
Sad to say, my first thought for “Buds go in them” was BONGS, which doesn’t fit, then PACK for a pack of Budweisers.

A very very nice challenge! I did need the revealer to crack the NW. I am a person who loves the late week puzzles (Thursday through Saturday) and I felt the same happiness completing this fun Wednesday offering.

I kept wanting to squeeze THETURNOFTHECREW into 17A, and had a heckuva time with the NW corner entries, but MICS, IMAC, and finally, Yeah, Mr. White, SCIENCE! at 4D enabled me to sort it all out. 

I've seen Oopsy, Upsy, and Upsa. It's just fill, so stay flexible, solvers. 

Doris Day had a TV sitcom from 1968 to 1973, so I don't think you're necessarily geriatric to have heard "Que SERA Sera", which was the theme song of the program. Nobody sent that song up better than Alfred Hitchcock in his 1956 remake of "The Man Who Knew Too Much" featured a scene where Doris Day's character loudly and endlessly sings the song at a foreign embassy where her son has been kidnapped. As with so many classic Hitchcock scenes, it's simultaneously horrific and dryly amusing.

I jumped and squealed for joy when I saw this beautiful tasty little diddy of a crossword on my chilly Wednesday morning! I suffer from life long incontinence of my bladder and bowel, and since this is a longer/harder crossword I needed a couple of diaper changes to get through. Nevertheless, she persisted. My favorite word was "UPSA DAISY" -- I've been saying it like that all my life like a normal person, insterad of "OOPSIE".

This was very much a Jekyl and Hyde work.  Some areas had great and inventive entries  Others had very questionable ones and it wasn't a question of rarely used words, rather a stretch too far ro make a word "work".  I don't like when solvng includees the thought "well, that's not really right but it's the only thing that fits".

Great puzzle. Tricky clues, superb wordplay. And the constructor notes are HAI-cute!
Thanks ladies!
Late comment - it seems no one else had LAWS for 3D: Something to make or break.  The bottom two-thirds was a piece of cake but the NW and NE were a beast for me.  Not a fan of  OHSAY and NOTDO!

This one was a struggle for me, I even checked to make sure it was a Wednesday and not a Thursday with hidden rebuses.

I just couldn't get the theme, and it didn't help that the revealer was the last part I filled in. It took me a while to figure out it was UPSA and not upsy, and then it finally clicked.... and I  laughed when the theme answers finally made sense. 

"Wrinkles in times" for AGES was a masterful clue on many levels.... one of my favorites.

Never encountered UPSA Daisy before though.  We say oopsy.
